author: @natalienurse403
text:
Re Serena - This is why knowing what else is going on for black people overseas is so important and actually listening to other black people in the diaspora. I'm a Black Brit and I immediately got the Serena scene. I tried to share this perspective, but people don't want to hear anything that is not . She was literally wearing a blue version of "the whites", (Wimbledon is all white, clothes & people lol). In the UK IT WAS HUGE!!!!!! Serena was criticised, ridiculed, racist cartoons, all over the news, this went on FOR WEEKS!!!!! not to mention the think pieces acting like she was trying to destroy the world of tennis!!!!!! She was given numerous suspensions, they tried to fine her into bankruptcy, they boo'd her everywhere she played. This then extended across European countries like France, Spain, Germany where she was continuously hounded and surveilled. She literally and metaphorically crip walked all over their stupid sport, she's the best ever and no-one can do anything about it!!!!! She left on her own terms, they really wanted her to be disgraced, they wanted to strip her of her accolades (they're obsessed with nakedness and shaming of black people). They would not stop, however she outsmarted them!!!! and they're STILL sick about it!!!!
Also
Re repping Compton, I have watched interviews where Serena and Venus have spoken about the local community protecting them whilst they practiced on the courts, especially at night. It was known and agreed to "leave them alone" and make sure they didn't get caught up in any cross-fire etc. The community were their cheerleaders and adamant that they were doing something admirable and could possibly be the greatest at their craft. 

Happy Black History Month cousins!!
‚ù§‚ô•üñ§üíö‚ù§üñ§

author: @CEN-Tyra
text:
It wasn‚Äôt until now that I understood why people didn‚Äôt understand the 40 acres and a mule line, because when I was growing up in the public education system in north Mississippi in the 90s we learned about this and things like the Homestead Act and about the unfairness of the government‚Äôs treatment of black folk and native folks.

I didn‚Äôt realize they haven‚Äôt been teaching this stuff due to racist legislation that‚Äôs been undermining the public education system for years now

replies.author: @ellievampmtf
replies.text: my partner‚Äôs mom who is in her 60‚Äôs didn‚Äôt know about the Trail of Tears and tons of the prosecution Native Americans faced until we taught her about it recently. our education system is wild.

if americans don‚Äôt know something happened before, they won‚Äôt know how to fight/defeat it.

author: @ericaa.1934
text:
The audacity to call out Kevin for being to much of a J.Lo hater when discussing Kendrick is wild. Have we not learned, this man is teaching us that the sky is the limit when it comes to being a hater. So in the year of our lord 2025, don‚Äôt ask if you are being too petty, ask how can you be pettier.
Jokes aside, I do get Kevin‚Äôs point. It is frustrating to see Latinos (typically of the lighter/more European variety) conveniently lean in to Latinidad. I think it‚Äôs also come up with the Emilia Perez discourse, how being Latino also has cultural aspects so just ‚Äúlooking‚Äù the part isn‚Äôt enough. When you only focus on that, you get movies like that made that only stereotype and exploit Latino countries and their struggles even though technically there were two Latinas in major roles in the movie.

author: @maryjack08
text: I'm a white girl from Aotearoa NZ, and it boggles my mind that so many Americans haven't heard of 40 acres and a mule. My high school history class covered it in 1999

replies.author: @sebastiaanv
replies.text: Congrats lol

replies.author: @mochalily3735
replies.text: Sadly that makes sense. America likes to rewrite history a lot. They misrepresent and minimize a lot of what happened during slavery, Jim Crow segregation, the civil rights movements, what truly happened to our leaders, and pretty much everything about the civil war. That‚Äôs part of why we see so many southern whites clinging to the confederacy and swearing it had nothing to do with slavery. They‚Äôre not being taught the real history. Some of our politicians have literally said they no longer want to teach the history of slavery because it might make the white kids feel bad ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è There‚Äôs A LOT that‚Äôs been removed from our history books.

replies.author: @maryjack08
replies.text: @mochalily3735¬† In hindsight I had an awesome school. One of the things we studied in depth was the American civil rights movement, and how South Africans paid attention to it & tried to use similar civil disobedience tactics in the 80s fighting back against apartheid. I had to write about the life and murder of Steve Biko.

replies.author: @maryjack08
replies.text:
@sebastiaanv¬† I just meant it's a fundamental piece of history, even internationally. Even in the 19th century, human rights movements had global impact and activists learned from each other. There are some things that don't make any sense if you remove a chunk as important as American independence, the Civil War, and Reconstruction.

Why did Britain and France expand into the Pacific and squabble over various islands? Because American independence (and then Irish independence too) gouged a hole in their ability to outsource growing food.

author: @lowtech42
text: On SZA's vocals: An audio engineer has said that her mic was indeed on, what you were hearing were her live, heavenly vocals and not a backing track. There is minimal vocal backing in the form of one background vocal line during "luther" (which happens around 8:11 in the NFL video) but the rest of what you hear is original vocal performance just like with Kendrick (although NLU had a couple bg vocals too). I say all this to combat the popular misconception of this phenomenal performance because plenty of OVO stans and other bad actors are running with this false narrative to diminish this show's greatness. Just like how this show is consistently great!!!

replies.author: @bouncyshak
replies.text: Where did you see that? I'm a singer. Honestly, the sound quality was so vastly different to Kendrick's and SLJ's and there are no breaths despite her choreo, so I'm not convinced. I've checked it on the Spotify recording and it definitely sounds like a track in comparison to everything else. But I don't even think it matters whether she sang onstage or not. She performed well, looked beautiful, that's still her voice and she sounded amazing.

replies.author: @lowtech42
replies.text: @bouncyshak Admittedly the mixing was terrible during the performance, which it usually is during the halftime show so that could explain the difference. The audio has been fixed in the official upload vs the live. Is it possible that me or the engineer are wrong? Sure is, I wasn't there. But by that metric, it would also mean that you could be wrong too. But I'm also basing my judgment off of her past live performances too. Unless the conclusion is that she just always lip syncs which just doesn't make sense. Why would she have been so upset about her vocal chords being damaged that one time then? People are so quick to call her a liar and then unironically (either intentionally or unintentionally) lie on her abilities! With no proof! Just listen to Crybaby, she be singing down forreal!!!

replies.author: @bouncyshak
replies.text: @lowtech42 I know how she sounds live. I mentioned elsewhere on this video that I saw her live last summer, and she sounded better than the recording mostly honestly. I'm just basing my opinion of her Superbowl performance on my technical knowledge of how microphones and vocals work. No pl0sives or breaths or vibrato is almost impossible on a massive stadium stage with constant movement and cold outside air etc. Even standing completely still you would get at least one of those. The other vocal performers had those. As I said, it doesn't matter and I fully understand if she didn't want to with a massive performance like this seeing as it's going to be viewed hundreds of millions of times and immortalised online.

replies.author: @kwill84
replies.text: @StarrMicaylabut her being flawless while doing a backbend is extremely difficult. She was crawling around and crunched over at certain times. You diaphragm and intercostal ribs are the muscle groups that assist your breathing. Contracting those muscles makes proper singing difficult. However as a former gymnast she could have done the work to open all of that up properly. In modern times you don‚Äôt see that skill level in popular musicians. You usually only see that level of training in broadway stars.  A perfect example of this is a video of Chloe and Hallie Bailey singing with Anika noni Rose to the princess and the frog. Their voices together were less impressive and powerful to Anika nonis voice alone. Because Anika is a classical trained vocalists.

author: @StonedHunter
text:
That point you guys made about not needing all the explanations to understand the core of the performance is so true. I started seeing breakdowns and decided to go watch it myself before I let myself get influenced by other people's thoughts...

And ya, I didn't understand all the details, I still understood the overall message. After that, going and looking into the details just helped me understand some specifics that I had missed and how they play into that overall message.

Breakdowns and explanations have their place, but too many people (hell even I'm guilty of this at times) are too comfortable taking in someone else's interpretation in place of experiencing it themselves instead of using it as supplemental information that it should be used as.

author: @gk.dopeesq.6853
text: I think it totally makes sense that people don't know the 40 Acres and a Mule history. These are things that must be taught and the bulk of America's education about black history boils down to white washed MLK, George Washington Carver (and only peanuts) and Rosa Parks (just to remind people black women exist).  Then not every family has the tools/resources, historical facts necessary to teach their kids this. Then not every black person has roots in the country, so like Rebecca says, it's something people have to learn.  We have to teach one another (and as an AA with a Jamaican wife, cross cultural education is important so that we don't tear black cultures down due to our differences and recognize just how much similarities there are).

text: 1:30:26 to me, the thing about the J Lo hate train, as someone who was born in 2000 and heard about her stealing from Ashanti for years but didn‚Äôt really know so many details about her until people started talking about her online recently, I think my strong dislike for her comes largely from the fact that I‚Äôm genuinely shocked we let her get this far. I think she should‚Äôve been washed up, especially since I never had a strong affinity towards her to begin with, judging her music on my own. Additionally, the onslaught started she made that movie where she complained about how few accolades and little credit she gets and, upon review, people realized not only is she so full of herself to think she deserves it knowing how her career formed, but she actually deserves less so people are trying to tell her that. All things considered, I think the hate is organic and 100% her fault for not being grateful she got to coast for so long and never had to earn a career, so I hope she sees it and I hope it keeps coming.

author: @mochalily3735
text:
1:30:08 So this Drake V Kendrick thing has shifted my perspective on the ‚Äúhate train‚Äù aka ‚Äúbandwagon‚Äù mentality. I no longer assume that people are just jumping on the bandwagon. To be clear, 1000% there ARE people who start hating an artist just to follow the crowd. 
But I‚Äôve learned that many are actually people who have disliked that particular artist for YEARS but because the artist was still popular, they stayed quiet until it was their time to shine üòÇ. Those people are the reason the hate trains pick up steam and why the hate doesn‚Äôt simply disappear when the next big thing happens. I was offended when a friend said I‚Äôm just jumping on the Drake hate train üò≠ because baby when I say I have not been able to tolerate that corny mf for YEARS üòÇ I mean it. I think it started around the peak of the Rihanna, Chris Brown, Drake drama. The way that man moved during that era told me exactly the kind of man he is and he‚Äôs been proving me right ever since. The fact that people are only now catching on to how weird, misogynistic, insecure and simpish that man is will forever amaze me. 
I saw a TikTok of this guy saying his main issue with the new Drake PND album is that he can‚Äôt relate to majority of what Drake is even talking about. He said Drake has a bar on one of the songs about a girl he‚Äôs talkin to and how she might get kicked out of her mom‚Äôs house. Aubrey is almost 40 YEARS OLD! How old are the women you entertaining that they‚Äôre still worried about getting put out their momma house?! ü§¶üèæ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüòÇ

When Meek exposed the ghostwriting, I thought ‚Äúsurely true rap fans won‚Äôt let this mf get away with this‚Äù‚Ä¶ I was disappointed. When Pusha exposed Adonis I thought ‚Äúsurely people will FINALLY see how trash this man is‚Äù and again I was disappointed. 
Meek wasn‚Äôt a big enough star and he looked like a hater. Pusha did damage but he wasn‚Äôt mainstream enough to do what Kendrick has done. 
Kendrick did EVERYTHING he needed to do and now, I‚Äôm at peace üòÇüòÇ. Is this the end of Drake? Absolutely not. The man is disgustingly rich and has very devoted fanboys. But the damage will never be undone and watching Rihanna, Serena and Meg get their lick back was chef‚Äôs kiss for me üòÇ

author: @ssft12056
text:
Re: 4 acres and a mule conversation

I think it's also important to keep in mind that education about disabled, Black, Indigenous, Brown, etc, and LGBTQ+ people, if offered at all, is routinely chipped away by people in power at the state and federal level. The only thing I remember learning about indigenous peoples in elementary school was about the trail of tears. Just like everything else, oppressed peoples were only mentioned when it impacted the oppressors. Stonewall Riots, Black Civil Rights Movement (there were many simultaneously, so I wanted to specify which one I was referring to. At that, only peaceful people, like MLK, Rosa Parks, and Ruby Bridges were mentioned), ADA passed, genocide committed against indigenous peoples.
Most of what I have learned about my own and fellow oppressed people's lives and history has been through middle school, high school, and college classes, some of which are elective to take.
Especially in our current economy, higher education - and, thus, classes about broader history - is inaccessible to most people. With that, the loss of information the average American faces is exacerbated.
